Text:
Over a thousand years ago, it was the golden age for
vampires.

Vampires hunted, devoured, and drank human blood
practically for sport.

Most of them saw humans as base livestock, and there
were even some countries where they reigned over them.

Amidst such times, only Lady Elisabeth detested
hunting more humans than was necessary.

She hunted only what was necessary to survive,
refusing to take their lives in excess. There was no
shortage of vampires who opposed her methods, so
despite her power, her followers numbered few.

Soon, though, the vampires entered their dark age.
The humans began hunting the vampires back,
turning the vampires' era into one of nightmares.

The destruction of the vampires' capital sparked the
fire of rebellion, and the vampires' numbers dwindled
in the blink of an eye.

At the time, Lady Elisabeth ruled a small human
country.

Vampires didn't look down on humans in her lands, nor
did humans fear vampires. The way they maintained
that relationship was by not drinking blood.

Without drinking human blood, vampires can't go on
living.

That was the prevailing belief at the time, but by
abstaining herself, Lady Elisabeth disproved this
theory.

Upon seeing her resolve, we followers of her did the
same.

As a result, we gradually lost our power, but we also
gained something in return.

The power to live under the sunlight and with
tranquility in our hearts, just like humans.

Our urge to drink blood gradually subsided, and we
became able to live in the beautiful, sunlit world.
But Lady Elisabeth was the exception.

Her skin would become inflamed when exposed to
sunlight, so she couldn't go outside without a
parasol. The only reason she didn't instantly turn to
ash was her inherent resistance to sunlight.

Also, no matter how long she went without blood,
her maddening urges never ceased.

Yet despite her agony, she carried out her life
beneath her parasol just the same as all the
others. Eventually, she gathered up her followers and
spoke to them.

Let us build a Haven here. A land where humans and
vampires can live in peace...

She recruited and protected vampires being pursued by
humanity. Of course, the condition for her protection
was that they give up blood.

Some of them resented her for this and revolted
against her. It was with a heavy heart that she had
to exile them. Some refused to comply, and those
she put down herself.

At some point, all the vampires in the world came
under human attack, and they all gathered under
Lady...Queen Elisabeth's banner.

Her population expanded, humans and vampires mingled
together, and her land prospered. She used her great
powers to defend her lands, so vampire hunters dared
not enter.
The Haven she'd set out to create was a success.

She prayed everyone would be able to continue living
in peace.

Then came the night when the Red Moon rises once in
a thousand years.

On that night, which granted vampires immense power,
she locked herself away in her castle to suppress her
bloodthirsty urges.

Back then, I was her second-in-command,
and Crimson was her third.

The two of us took turns bringing her meals, but when
it was Crimson's turn, tragedy struck.

Crimson allowed a single drop of blood to touch the
blood-starved Lady Elizabeth's lips.

If she'd been at her best, she might have noticed its
scent before she ate it. Or maybe she would have
eaten it but still been able to withstand her urges.
But that was the night of the Red Moon.

She had been without blood for too long, and she
wasn't able to stop herself from going on a rampage.
Crimson and his followers rose up in unison.
Her dream, the Haven...had all been a mere fantasy.

Lady Elisabeth's rampage lasted three days and two
nights.

The Haven was reduced to rubble, and three
kingdoms were wiped out.

Because Elisabeth's followers had stopped drinking
blood, they were powerless to resist, and they were
slain as they fled.

I survived by lapping up the blood of the dead, and I
pursued Lady Elisabeth.
I found her after it was all over.
Please, cast my ashes into the sea...
...so I can never rise again...
...and repeat this mistake...

Lady Elisabeth then drove a dagger into her own
heart.

A regular vampire would have immediately turned to
ashes...
But Lady Elisabeth didn't.

Her heart stopped, and her lungs no longer breathed.
It was as if she were dead.

If I placed human blood in her mouth, she would
instantly be resuscitated.

Alternatively, if I gave the dagger a small push,
she would instantly turn to ash.

I couldn't go against her will, but I couldn't bring
myself to kill her, either. Instead, I vowed to
protect my slumbering queen until the end of days.
